body_html:
@argman Building Tensorflow with Bazel on Windows should work out of the box now.

  1. Download bazel-0.8.1-windows-x86_64.exe from https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases, rename it to bazel.exe and put it in PATH.
  2. set BAZEL_VS or BAZEL_VC to point to your VS 2017 installation directory (see https://docs.bazel.build/versions/master/windows.html)
  3. Clone Tensorflow.
  4. Run configure.py (see https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_sources).
  5. Open .tf_configure.bazelrc and remove -march=native (otherwise the console output will be very noisy).
  6. Set TMP, TEMP and TMPDIR to shorter name like C:\tmp due to bazelbuild/bazel#4149.
  7. Run bazel build --config=opt //tensorflow/tools/pip_package:build_pip_package.

If the build seems to stuck at compiling conv_grad_ops_3d.cc and conv_ops_3d.cc, don't worry about it. These two files are known to take a very long time to compile in MSVC due to __force_inline. The compilation will eventually finish. See #10521.

body:
@argman Building Tensorflow with Bazel on Windows should work out of the box now.

1. Download `bazel-0.8.1-windows-x86_64.exe` from https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases, rename it to `bazel.exe` and put it in `PATH`.
1. set `BAZEL_VS` or `BAZEL_VC` to point to your VS 2017 installation directory (see https://docs.bazel.build/versions/master/windows.html)
1. Clone Tensorflow.
1. Run `configure.py` (see https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_sources).
1. Open `.tf_configure.bazelrc` and remove `-march=native` (otherwise the console output will be very noisy).
1. Set `TMP`, `TEMP` and `TMPDIR` to shorter name like `C:\tmp` due to bazelbuild/bazel#4149.
1. Run `bazel build --config=opt //tensorflow/tools/pip_package:build_pip_package`.

If the build _seems_ to stuck at compiling `conv_grad_ops_3d.cc` and `conv_ops_3d.cc`, don't worry about it. These two files are known to take a very long time to compile in MSVC due to `__force_inline`. The compilation will eventually finish. See #10521.
